author: ixamnis
body:
I see several people on here suggesting VOO.  I have no problem with VOO, but be aware that the top six holdings in VOO are:  AAPL, MSFT, AMZN, FB, GOOGL and GOOG.  I like VOO, but if you want to diversify outside of tech you may want to consider some value stocks and buy individual stocks instead of an ETF, or buy sector ETFs.  

Value stocks that I'd recommend:  ABBV, ACN, AES, CLX, DIS, IBM, JNJ, JPM, KHC, KO, KR, LOW, MA, MAR, MCD, NVS, O, PEP, PFE, PLAY, SBUX, T, TD, TGT, TROW, VZ, WBA, WMT, WSM. I think you could easily pick any three to five of these and have a nicely balanced portfolio given the amount of money you are investing.

Sector ETFs that I like include:

ICLN, TAN or PBW - Clean energy/renewable energy

FHLC, XLV - Health Care

IDNA, ARKG - Genomic Research and DNA technology

PRNT - 3D printing

ARKQ, THNK, ROBO - artificial intelligence and robotics (However, this is "tech")

VFH, FNCL, XLF, IEFN - financial sector ETFs

I'm not a financial advisor and have no business giving financial advice. That said, a nice balanced portfolio might look something like this:

33% tech stocks and ETFs  (This is what you already have)

33% value stocks (from the list above)

33% sector ETFs:  10% ICLN, 10% ARKG, 10% XLV

Best of luck to you.

author: totsnotbiased
body:
So what I would do with your Lowe’s stock is sell out of about 5% of it per year as long as it’s looking well rated, and take that money along with the dividends and buy into growth industries un-correlated with Lowe’s (like heathcare, Tech etc)

This way if it’s growing more than 5% a year, your principal isn’t shrinking, but you are less reliant on Lowe’s alone.

My opinion on the AMC/INTC/NVDA wars is they will all go up, and buy all three so you don’t miss a breakout! So I’d buy in NVDA a little bit, as it also Wall Street’s favorite out of the three

Accenture is a good investment, I like that quite a bit

Also can’t go wrong with buying in VOO and QQQ, and for younger investor’s ARKK is personally where it’s at too.

Amazon is a decent hedge against Lowe’s too that I’d think about

author: styledliving
body:
A good example is COVID-19 tracking in the UK and US. 

The recent reports that people had underlying causes that contributed to increased fatality was directly attributed by using the Palantir platform because it was able to not only ingest data from multiple disparate sources (apparently the CDC had a previous system to track pandemic indicators for flu and stuff, but they didn't track all the patient data you needed.  

From previous sales material on how Palantir ingests data from like business cards to table napkins with technical drawings.  I think the way they did it was all the hospital forms and documents, they used their Image recognition module to scan all the paper forms that were faxed over from all the hospitals.  They were also flexible in ingesting data from various database schemas. 

Like if you think about big data in terms of health care, nobody has the same way of storing data in a database.  Some databases are literally just f\*cking file cabinets.  Other places have a form that has maybe 15 cells for name, dob, blood type, pre-existing conditions, are they missing limbs, that sorta thing.  Other hospitals/healthcare providers will be voracious in their patient history and note taking even down to what bed they stayed in and how many times their sheets were changed in an inpatient visit.

This is the problem w/ data and an even bigger problem w/ big data.  Trying to sift through the information that's relevant and also providing correlating links to data that \*shoudn't\* be relevant but ends up being relevant.  Researchers are able to do research and ask questions and get answers (in the form of data) from whatever analysis tool.  The difference is (as mentioned above) how long support requests take place.  Like when you're writing a book, you immediately do research to find out something so you can keep your creative momentum.  

Researchers operate much in the same way where if it takes too long from a vendor to complete an ask, the creative momentum is crushed.

I think we should be clear here, Palantir has shown it can scale within its confines and it's successful at helping people. 

The actual question that we should be asking is:

With another 4.5-9 billion in additional cash, can it increase adoption?  

If the answer is a linear progression or even algebraic, it can beat out Accenture, Gartner, IBM, PWC, and etc.  I'd say continued long-term increase.  I'd liken Palantir to Tesla's Battery day.  Not right now, but 2022 look for a moonshot if you can HODL.

author: PoopKing5
body:
Since you’re talking very long term, not quite sure I agree with CRWD, DDOG, TDOC, ROKU and potentially Intel. It feels those could potentially be more of a 3-5 year buy at this point and if you’re not really planning on actively trading it, just feel that those companies are not as high probability like a more blue chip portfolio. You could argue intel could stay in. 

I’d maybe add Adobe, Abbott, Intuit, CRM, Accenture. 

If you’re more trading the account then sure, maybe those other names could be a benefit but if you’re just looking for low turnover buy and hold, I’d maybe stick to some “higher quality.”

author: styledliving
body:
I think the difference is intimate knowledge of the product.  Other firms who wrangle data are usually on the consultant space like Accenture.  They take some COTS platform and build from scratch the ontologies and tooling to go with it.  Customization takes as much billable hours in stupid meetings as possible so they can justify recruiting whole teams and keep their hiring engine positive.  Palantir saves money in the long run despite what analysts call expensive customizations because it's those gov't agencies' first foray into big data because other consulting agencies have many times been just too frickin' expensive.

See Center for Public Integrity's brief mention: [https://publicintegrity.org/health/coronavirus-and-inequality/secretive-data-system-shaping-pandemic-response-hhs-protect/](https://publicintegrity.org/health/coronavirus-and-inequality/secretive-data-system-shaping-pandemic-response-hhs-protect/)

Another place that I see Palantir make sense is that they're agile in terms of being able to make customer optimizations since they own the platform and the customer consultancy vertical.  Intimate knowledge of the customer, intimate knowledge of the platform, and belief in the customer's mission (the palantirians sound like a cult for social change). Maybe good, maybe bad, but at least it means that your vendor has your back .. that's a pretty rare thing.  I don't see Amazon having my back on the AWS side or on the Employee (think warehouse and covid19) side.

It appears to me if there're sufficiently technically savvy customers, customers can use their own analysts to make their own customizations, those deployments would likely make more money for the company as adoption increases, I think that was the cases in one of the energy industry implementations in their investor day video.

Technology, the product might not be as sophisticated as the computer on the Starship Enterprise making up Moriarti's, but they're using the sh\*t out of it and making it work.

Enter Scuderia Ferrari:

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k80R6fgf2ME](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k80R6fgf2ME)

author: styledliving
body:
They might be different, in a different thread last week, someone compared them with other gov't contractors.  Response time was days vs weeks at implementing new features.

Let me say that again **IMPLEMENTING NEW FEATURES**. 

Those that work in gov't *know how big this* is because contracts are usually set in stone and once folks like Accenture, PWC, Gartner, etc get their contracts signed, they send in interns to do the dirty work.  PTLR apparently still sends in their best guys after the initial implementation.  

So for IPO, I'm not sure how this affects them, probably not a whole lot, but long term, Palantir will either bring about a new standard within the tech consulting industry et al, or *they will be the new standard*.

**Events in the US Today (EDT):**

* 8:30am - Initial Jobless Claims \[3/3 Volatility\]
* 9:00am - The House meets
* 10:00am - Fed Chair Powell Testifies \[3/3 Volatility\]
* Treasury Secretary Mnuchin Speaks \[2/3 Volatility\]
* New Home Sales (Aug) \[3/3 Volatility\]
* 10:45am - Nancy Pelosi holds her weekly press conference
* 11:00am - KC Fed Composite & Manuf. Indexes \[1/3 Volatility\]
* The House begins legislative business
* 11:30am - 4&8 Week Bill Auctions \[1/3 Volatility\]
* 1:00pm - Chicago Fed Pres. Evans Speaks \[1/3 Volatility\]
* 7-Year Note Auction \[1/3 Volatility\]
* 2:00pm - FOMC Member Williams Speaks \[3/3 Volatility\]
* 4:30pm - POTUS delivers remarks on the America First Healthcare Vision
* Charlotte, NC
* Comments from President Donald Trump that he would not commit to a peaceful transfer of power should he lose the election appeared to hit sentiment. Investors are concerned about a drawn-out election result.
* On Wednesday Chair Powell reiterated that further fiscal stimulus is needed if the U.S. economic recovery is to continue.
* Disney said it plans to move the release of a number of its coming slate of movies into late 2020 and 2021 as Americans continue to shun indoor movie theaters amid the pandemic.
* Disney pushed the release of the much-anticipated Marvel blockbuster “Black Widow” back by 6 months to May 2021. The studio also postponed for a full year the release for the remake of “West Side Story” to Dec 2021 from its previous Dec 2020 date.
* Johnson & Johnson on Wednesday began an enormous late-stage human trial in the United States and in other countries to test the effectiveness and safety of a single-dose vaccine to ward off COVID-19 infection.

author: ixamnis
body:
Here are some that I like. By no means an exhaustive list:

**QQQ** \- This one uses the NASDAQ 100 as its benchmark. Obviously it's an Indexed, non-managed ETF. XTF used to rate this one as a perfect 10.0 out of 10 rating, but recently dropped it to 9.9 out of 10. It has one of the highest rates of return over the past 10 years of any ETF. It does tend to be tech-heavy, especially with the FAANG +M stocks.  (Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix, Google and Microsoft).  Other top holdings include TSLA, NVDA and ADBE.  (The rating dropped recently when the portfolio of the NASDAQ 100 was re-balanced).

**VXUS** \- Vanguard Total International Index Fund ETF - top holdings include BABA, Tencent, Samsung, Taiwan Semiconductors, Novartis, Toyota. This is a broad market fund investing only in companies overseas.  I'm not generally bullish on foreign markets, but this one is a very solid ETF with some companies that are likely to do extremely well for the foreseeable future.  XTF rates this one a perfect 10.0 out of 10.

**VOO**/**SPY** \- **VOO** and **SPY** are non-managed funds indexed to the S&P 500 Index. These funds are very popular on this subreddit, for good reason. They are well diversified, broad market funds investing in mostly US stocks. XTF rates these funds at 9.6 out of 10 because their return on investment over the long term is somewhat tempered by some of the blue chip stocks in the funds. But those stocks also help reduce volatility relative to some other ETFs. These are solid investments, but keep in mind that in the top 10 holdings there will be a lot of crossover between these funds and other broad market funds that hold US stocks like **QQQ**, **VTI**, **VTG**, **VOOG** and **SPYG**.  There are differences, of course, as well, but you always want to know where those duplications exist.

**IWF** \- This is a Russell 1000 indexed fund. It is one of my favorites that doesn't get talked about much. It does have a lot of crossover with the other funds mentioned above, but the mix is slightly different.  I would describe this fund as more aggressive than **VOO/SPY**, less volatile than **QQQ**.

**IWM** \- for someone looking to diversify a little bit, this is a great fund to look into. This fund is a non-managed, indexed fund that uses the Russell 2000 index as its benchmark. The big difference between the Russell 2000 index and many of the the other indexes is that the Russell 2000 index looks at small and mid-cap companies, rather than large-cap companies.  Thus, there is zero crossover between this one and the funds mentioned above. While this fund will move up and down with the market, it is often less volatile than the market overall. If you look at the charts, this fund has under-performed some of the other funds over the past few months while the market has been very volatile in an upward direction, but in a crash, this fund would probably outperform the rest of the market.  It has a 9.0/10 XTF rating.

There are also some sector funds you may want to look at:

&#x200B;

**ICLN**/**TAN/FAN** \- These funds are clean/renewable energy ETFs. ICLN is more broad while TAN focuses more specifically on solar energy and FAN specifically on wind generated energy. I think renewable energy companies are the future. There is no crossover in the top holdings of this fund with the top holdings of QQQ and most of the other broad market funds. Also, these are global, not just US based companies.  QCLN and PBW are also renewable energy funds, but they also contain a lot of TSLA, NIO and W.K. H.S. in their top holdings making them "electric vehicle" funds, as well.  No problem if you want to add that, but you'll find a lot of Tesla in some of the funds mentioned above.

**ARK** group of funds: **ARKG**, **ARKF**, **ARKK ARKW**, **ARKQ**, **PRNT** and **IZRL**. These are managed funds investing in companies that invest in disruptive companies in their respective industries. Most posters on this subreddit are bullish on these funds. They are aggressive growth ETFs, but should be considered somewhat risky and volatile.

* ARKG - Genomic Revolution
* ARKF - Fintech
* ARKK - Disruptive Companies (broader market)
* ARKW - Internet/computer/technology  (Telsa is a top holding)
* ARKQ - Robotics and artificial intelligence
* PRNT - 3D printing technology
* IZRL - disruptive companies based in Israel

XL series of funds.  Similar to the ARK series, these tend to be more aggressive growth funds, however these are passively managed indexed funds with various benchmarks that usually are overloaded in the better companies within a sector:

* **XLV** \- Health Care
* **XLK** \- Technology
* **XLY** \- Consumer Discretionary
* **XLF** \- Financial
* **XLU** \- Utilities

***A nice portfolio might look something like this:***

20% - Broad market US fund such as QQQ, VOO or IWF

20% - VXUS - International

20% - IWM - Small/Mid-cap broad market fund

10% each in four sector funds of your choice

Hope this helps.

&#x200B;

*I'm not a financial expert or advisor and this is not financial advice, just an opinion from a random internet person.  I do own shares in several, but not all of the funds listed above, including QQQ, IWF, some ARK funds, ICLN, VXUS, etc.*

&#x200B;

**EDIT:**  WOW! Thanks for the awards and the positive comments.  I appreciate the feedback.  I hope this advice really helps some people.

body:
I'm long-term bullish on Unity due to the potential of it being the next Adobe, AutoDesk, etc and the fact that the market is definitely a lot bigger for there to be a player outside of Epic Games (especially with most of Unity's revenue coming from ads/e-commerce rather than licensing like Epic)

But short-term, I expect this price to come down. It's extremely odd to say the least that Unity and Snowflake are rocketing up while the rest of tech is coming down...it points to the fact that growth/tech investors are parking their money here and will be shorted later. So I believe in unity long term, but I'm going to wait to jump in.

author: PegBundysBonBons
body:
Yea, I know its overpriced.

Here's the thing tho: Shit always works

I had a macbook pro that lasted about 8 years of solid use. It started to act up near the end of its life but otherwise had a good track record.

Then because I was cheap I replaced it with a Lenovo Thinkpad running windows. I was immediately reminded of the bullshit I used to have to deal with almost instantaneously.

Go to print- must install drivers- great

Get drivers installed- then it prints it out in super small script for ants

Can't get the print size to change so I have to save as a pdf and install Adobe

Always a fuckin hassle working on windows I dont care what anybody says.

Pull out my old macbook, prints right away, no issue.

author: VirtuousGallantry
body:
[Barron’s covers it well](https://www.barrons.com/articles/what-is-going-on-with-the-stock-market-heres-one-answer-51599241222): 

“Barron’s previously reported that Softbank had started making big bets on tech stocks, including Amazon, Alphabet, and Adobe (ADBE), during the June quarter.

Whether it was all SoftBank or not is moot. Bullish call-option buying has exploded. Over the past month, traders have bought almost 15 times the number of call options expiring in November of those FAANG stocks, plus Microsoft and Tesla, than the equivalent number of put options.

....


When call-option buying spikes, it drives call sellers to buy underlying stock, sending shares higher. When brokers sell options contracts, they don’t want to take the risk of what happens to the underlying stock. Brokers only want to earn a commission selling—and trading—the options. Often times, brokers buy underlying stock to hedge their book of business. That way, any gains or losses on options positions are offset by corresponding gains in the underlying stock prices.

So any explosion in call-option buying generates stock buying on the Street. That’s one way to explain the 20% rise of those tech stocks since July.

It’s also a way to explain the recent two day collapse. Call-option trading volume Thursday in those tech stocks was down by roughly two-thirds compared with recent highs.”

  Adobe has consistent growth and is a brand name tech stock. It also almost never has headlines that screw up technicals. Their CEO a few weeks ago said on CNBC that their income has increased because of Covid. Be very careful about today's panic, and good luck.

author: HatchCannon
body:
Physical media is nice for the following reasons:

First, 20 years down the line,you can pop in the disc in and play it. With downloaded, if the drive fails and you are outside of that supported systems life its too bad for you. Take care of your stuff, as you would with anything else, and it will be fine.

Second, you are dependent on that service to obtain games, as soon as it goes away, you have to repurchase it on whatever the new manner is. I have already, within my lifetime, seen numerous digital services go out of service or move to a new platform where you are told to pound sand on previous purchases, same will be the case for your game. 70 now, 30 on the next platform, 10 on the next one when they bring it back as some "retro" feature so you can buy it a third time. 

third, no inherent value to it. Now you are buying a game that is 60+ dollars, they can remove from your system if they want, the console can fail like with above, if they no longer support it its too bad for you. I have had older console games appreciate substantially from the nostalgia alone and that is gone now.

&#x200B;

Optical media sucks but I think it should be a staple of gaming, once they fully move off optical media its really going to sting. Can't wait for them to move to a pay per month service just to have the console (not to just play online) kind of like Adobe did with their product line or Microsoft with office suite /s. Won't support em.

author: GromGrommeta
body:
>potential of it being the next Adobe

I believe that's the promise of Unity. It's well-established in gaming, and sure that'll continue. But the promise is that they will become a software juggernaut serving a multitude of industries.

To quote the company's website, its software has applications to "Animation, Film, Automotive, Transportation, Architecture, Engineering, Manufacturing & Construction."

That's a pretty large TAM right there if they can establish themselves as a major player in just a few of those industries.

Took a small position, will wait for dips/consolidation before considering making it bigger. I also don't think it's a bad idea to wait for them to really get a foothold in some of these areas of lateral expansion before buying (even if by then it's at a higher price).

author: Summebride
body:
I think Adobe continues to have no competition and has actually benefited from pandemic.  

The con is that they have apparently transitioned 90% to subscription, which of course is less exciting than when they were just beginning that transition.  Is their high P/E as justifiable now that a lot of that growth transition has been achieved?

It's a worry that can solve itself if the earnings denominator shoots up.  

But if not, fickle investors could decide to take profits.  I did, high 300's, just before COVID, hoping to rebuy it lower, like under $300.  Missed my chance so I had to rebuy in the $400's, current exit target of $600.  I also have a long shot hope of it, and/or Google doing a split.

The counter is that as Adobe has owned the creative and content and document clouds, they are starting to dip into ecommerce.  If that shows promise, it could attract more longs.

author: Summebride
body:
Well I've had lots of such analysis in my coverage universe, but I should just tell you often it ends up not being investable information.  

Everything above about Netflix was knowable a year ago, but if you saw it and decided not to buy Netflix, you'd have missed gains.  

Sometimes it works out beautifully.  I recently knew of a pharma situation where one company had exclusive patent and proven therapy for peanut allergies, approvals rolling in worldwide, patients being quietly and successfully treated.  The company was backstopped by a big multinational, so the risk of BK was non-existent.  It was easy to imagine parents would certainly pay handsomely to protect their affected children against this common problem.  The stock was being heavily shorted down during pandemic but it always seemed like someday it would emerge from that or get bought.  It did, and AIMT ripped +175% on the buy-out.  But as I say, it doesn't usually work like that.  I've had similar situations where the buy-out happens closer to the shorted down cap, so having the correct thesis and taking the risk doesn't even pay off.  

I guess the most macro view is more of wishful thinking: that democrat victory will then lead to a realistic infrastructure stimulus and we'll see a huge rotation out of ultra high P/E tech and into some things that have been moribund for years.  I'm already starting to swap things like Adobe and Semis for materials and oil and banks.
